resources.string: The heart is a muscle with one of the most important jobs in the body. It pumps blood to our organs, making sure our cells get the nutrients and oxygen they need.

There are four different areas of the heart, called chambers. The atrium is at the top-left and oxygen-rich blood enters from the lungs. The blood flows from the atrium to the left ventricle, and is then pumped from the heart to the rest of the body.

The right atrium receives blood that has been around the body ready for more oxygen. The right ventricle pumps blood to the lungs via the pulmonary artery where it is cleaned of carbon dioxide and refilled again with oxygen. Four valves between the atriums and ventricles make sure blood always flow in the right direction

The heart responds to the body\'s need for oxygen by adjusting the speed it beats at, and the amount of blood it pumps with each beat. During exercise, the heart can increase the amount of blood it pumps up to five times. The normal resting heart rate for a human is 60 to 70 beats every second.
It takes 16 seconds for your blood to be pumped from the heart all the way down to your toes and back again.
If it continued to have a supply of oxygen, the heart would keep beating outside of the body.
The lungs take oxygen from the air and remove carbon dioxide from the body.

The air enters through the mouth or nose. It travels down the trachea, spits off between the two bronchi, which then branch off further into 30,000 bronchioles. The bronchioles end in alveoli, which are tiny air sacs. There is 300 million of them in the lungs! The alveoli are surrounded by blood vessels called capillaries, filled with red blood cells.

Red blood cells are doughnut shaped, and carry the oxygen and carbon dioxide in them all around the body. As the blood flows pas the alveoli, carbon dioxide floats out the red blood cell into the lungs, where it gets breathed back out. The empty red blood cells are then refilled with oxygen and go back around the body.
The diaphragm and rib muscles contract to increase space and lower the air pressure in the lungs, so air flows in.
When the rib and diaphragm muscles relax, the space in the lungs decreases. This increases the air pressure to push the air out of the lungs.
Out of all organs in the human body, the lungs are the only ones that can float on water.
The longest someone has managed to hold their breath was just over 20 minutes.

The stomach is a J-shaped organ that digests food. It produces enzymes (substances that create chemical reactions) and acids (digestive juices). This mix of enzymes and digestive juices breaks down food so it can pass to your small intestine.

Your stomach is part of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract. The GI tract is a long tube that starts at your mouth. It runs to your anus, where stool leaves your body. The GI tract is a key part of your digestive system.

Your stomach sits in your upper abdomen on the left side of your body. The top of your stomach connects to a valve called the esophageal sphincter (a muscle at the end of your esophagus). The bottom of your stomach connects to your small intestine.

The size of the stomach varies from person to person. Your stomach expands when full and deflates when empty. Because of this, your stomach size can vary depending on how recently and how much you have eaten.
The cardia is the top part of your stomach. It contains the cardiac sphincter, which prevents food from traveling back up your esophagus.
The fundus is a rounded section next to the cardia. It is below your diaphragm (the dome-shaped muscle that helps you breathe).
The body (corpus) is the largest section of your stomach. In the body, your stomach contracts and begins to mix food.
The antrum lies below the body. It holds food until your stomach is ready to send it to your small intestine.
The pylorus is the bottom part of your stomach. It includes the pyloric sphincter. This ring of tissue controls when and how your stomach contents move to your small intestine.

A square is two-dimensional because it has only height and width. It turns into a 3-D cube when we give it depth. A cube is made of 6 squares, or faces. Since all squares have the same height and width, the cube mush have a depth that is the same size also.
A cube is also called a hexahedron because it is a polyhedron with 6 (hexa- means 6) faces.
Surface Area = 6 × (Edge Length)^2
Volume = (Edge Length)^3
It has 12 edges.
It has 8 vertices (corner points).
Each face has 4 edges.

A pyramid is a three-dimensional shape. It has triangular sides that come together in a point at the top, call the "apex". A pyramid with a square base (bottom) and four sides is called a square pyramid. A pyramid with a triangular base and is called a tetrahedron.
Surface Area = [Base Area] + ½ × Perimeter × [Slant Length]
Volume = ⅓ × [Base Area] × Height
It has 4 faces.
The 3 Side Faces are triangles.
The base can be a triangle or a square.
A sphere is a shape in space that is like the surface of a ball. Usually, the words ball and sphere mean the same thing.
In mathematics, a sphere is the surface of a ball, which is given by all the points in three dimensional space that are located at a fixed distance from the center.
The distance from the center is called the radius of the sphere. When the sphere is filled in with all the points inside, it is called a ball.
It is perfectly symmetrical.
All points on the surface are the same distance "r" from the center.
It has one surface (not a "face" as it is not flat).
